牆

20 Jan 26 UTC Category: Sketch

カベ

毎朝の儀式は、自分の歯の数を確かめることだった。

ブラシを口に押し込み、その刷毛の一本一本を舌先で感じ取る。それは粗硬な植物繊維で編まれ、歯磨きジェルは淡い桃色の粘性を帯び、甘くも生臭い匂いを放つ。最も繊細な肉の破片を粉砕し、鉱物の粉末と練り合わせた──と囁かれている。瞼を閉じるのは、享受のためではない。ただ舌先に意識を集中し、一本ずつを確かに数えたいからだ。

一顆、兩顆…… 臼齒區似乎比昨天更擁擠了。有一顆邊緣銳利得像玻璃碎片的新牙，正從我左下方牙床的肉裏冷酷地向外撐開。不是單純的酸脹，顎骨深處的鈍力以某種深沉的頻率捶打着我過度拉伸的三叉神經，扯弄着延伸至頭皮及大腿的神經。

我刷得更加用力，幾乎是帶着一種自虐的決心。五十七根粗糙的纖維刺進牙肉隙間摩擦，水平地撕開新生的肉芽。牙膏的泡沫在我嘴裏迅速膨脹，變成一團溫熱、黏稠的漿液，那味道不是薄荷的清涼，而是一種類似於牆體在潮濕天氣裡，「出汗」時腐敗與生機的分泌氣味。

我在清潔我的牙齒，或者說，我正試圖把牆從我的口中刷去，卻又同時用着牆的一部分，為它在我體內的擴張，進行着最後的拋光與填充。

──漱ぐと、吐き出したのは薄赤く濁っている、食べかすと米粒ほどの白い欠片を携えて戻ってくる。それが昨夜の肉片か、早逝した新牙の一欠か、見分けはつかない。

交換

昨日刮ぎ取った一籠分の肉片を、路地角にある「交換機」へ運ぶ。誰によって作られたのか誰も知らない。まるで壁から自然に生えてきた金属質の腫瘍のように見える。私は肉片を上部の漏斗へ注ぎ込む。機械の内部からは低いうなりが響き、反芻する化物の咀嚼音を思わせる。ただ、緩やかに時間を刻むその振動を待つ。

肉屑，是這個世界上唯一的、永恆的複製品。每一片都呈現出幾乎完全一致的方形，質地均勻，像工業流水線上生產出來的、毫無個性的產品。我們刮取、交換、汲食、排泄、而排泄物又被牆根的菌叢吸收，成為牆新的養分。一個完美的、自我封閉的循環。

やがて機械下部の小さな排出口に緑のランプがともる。父の杜松子酒の瓶をそこに置く、透明な液体が滑り落ちるように注がれて満たされた。私は一片の肉屑で、一瓶の液状の肉屑を手に入れる。その液瓶を、固形を貪りすぎて崩壊しつつある父の身体に注ぐつもりだ。このエシックスは、あまりにも明晰だった。

父親的研磨機

父親年輕時，並不刮牆。他曾是個「工程師」。他花了數年時間，用撿來的廢銅爛鐵，組裝了一台他稱之為「全自動高頻振動式蛋白質採集器」的機器。

我記不得那機器的樣子，只記得它運轉時的聲音。沒有刮刀切入肉體的沉悶聲，那是一種高頻的尖細蜂鳴。父親驕傲地把它推到牆邊，按下了按鈕。機器的前端，一個裝滿了細小金屬刷頭的圓盤高速旋轉起來，貼上了牆面。

它沒有刮下任何東西。在毛躁的蜂鳴聲中，那塊它接觸過的牆面，開始變得異常光滑。所有的紋理、褶皺都被磨平了，呈現出一種詭異、半透明、如同打了蠟一般的油亮光澤；甚至開始向外滲出晶瑩剔透的、果凍狀的黏液，散發着比空氣更甜、更膩的氣味。

那台拋光機，最終被拆毀了。而那塊被拋光的牆面，在接下來的幾個月裏，再也沒有剝落過一片肉屑。它像一道疤痕，一個笑話，永遠地留在了那裏。父親從此再也沒碰過任何工具，除了那隻杜松子酒瓶。

監工

監工阿甲今日的訓話，是關於「刮削角度的最優化」，就在那塊被拋光的、像疤痕一樣的牆面前。他的聲音平滑得像那塊被拋光的牆面。

他不用鞭子，也不用拳頭。他用語言。一種由技術術語、生物學名詞和純粹的臆想混合而成的、無法辯駁的語言。

「注意你們的入刀角，」一股煙味，「必須維持在三十七點五度。過高會導致基底層的應激性收縮，過低則會增加角質蛋白的剝離率。你們要感受牆的『反饋』，要與基質的生物電場達成同步。」

沒有人交頭接耳。我下意識望了望同工們，他們點了頭，於是我也點了頭。

「三十七點五度……基底層……生物電場……」

那聲音從我嘴裡發出，卻又如此陌生，彷彿是另一個人、有另一個人在我的身體裏、有另一個人、彷彿是另一個人在我的身體裏、彷彿是另一個人在我的身體裏説話。

朧げで不明瞭

私はついに鏡一枚手に入れた。監督の阿甲が捨てた、金属製杜松子酒瓶の破片だ。縁はかなり鋭く尖っている、人前で確かめる勇気は正直ない。巣穴のように湿気の多い部屋に戻ってから、壁が発するかすかな微光を頼りにそっと、自分の顔を覗き込んだ。

そこに映っていたのは、液化しつつある顔だった。目鼻立ちの境界が曖昧で、皮膚はいつ剥がれ落ちてもおかしくない凝膠の膜のように揺らめいている。しかし、それが問題ではかった。

我強迫自己，去看那雙眼睛。

我預期會看到恐懼，或是一種被同化的、死寂的絕望。但我什麼也沒看到。那雙瞳孔裡沒有「我」，也沒有「他人」。它們不是井，不是深淵，它們就是鏡子本身。它們只負責反射，不負責存在。它們反射着房間裡濕潤的牆壁，反射着我那隻舉着鏡子的、同樣在液化的手，反射着鏡片上反射出的、更小的一個瞳孔，那個瞳孔裡又反射着一個更小的房間、手、和瞳孔……

肉

父親死的時候沒有發出聲音。前一天晚上他還在劇烈地咳嗽，第二天清晨，那聲音就消失了，像一台耗盡了燃料的機器，安靜了下來。他就那麼躺着，瘦得像根被抽乾了水分的甘蔗，皮膚底下淡青色的血管清晰可見，彷彿只要輕輕一碰，那層薄薄的皮就會像浸濕的紙一樣破裂。

我沒有去找監工。我讓他躺在那裡，躺了三天，讓房間裡的氣味變得非常濃郁，杜松子酒的植物氣息，被一種更強大、更根本的甜腥味徹底覆蓋。

第三天，我去搬動他的身體。我發現他笑着——父親被吹脹到極限——半透明的皮囊，一鍋用文火慢燉了整夜的肉湯，骨髓深處的油脂和膠質，都已徹底化進了湯裡，散發出那種近乎膩人的豐腴香氣。一塊烹煮好的、帶皮的紅肉黏在床上，被體內的壓力撐得緊繃而油亮，呈現出一種醬紫色與蠟黃色交錯的、誘人的光澤。那些皮下的薑黃的脂肪，已經完全液化，讓整具軀體顯得晶瑩剔透，軟糯而富有彈性。

我伸出手，指尖輕輕按了一下他腫脹的腹部。那觸感溫熱、柔軟，像按在一塊燉得極其軟爛的蹄髈上。我的指尖輕易地陷了進去，隨即，一個幾乎無法察覺的、細小的氣泡，從附近一個毛孔中，帶着一絲輕微的嘶嘶聲逸出一柱瓊漿，流溢出父親孕育的無數蠕動的生機。

我試着去搬動他。他不再是一具由骨骼和關節組成的身體，而是一整塊無分彼此的、巨大的肉塊。當我終於將他從床上挪開時，他那黏在床板上的皮膚，發出了一種濕潤的、黏牙的撕裂聲，就像是從鍋底鏟起一塊黏住了的、燉得膠質都已融化的肉皮。

把他抬走後，我試圖掀開那張又濕又沉的床墊——已經醃透了，把手掌按在上面，撲咕哧一下滲出來。

父親的床，是他身體緩慢又沉默的延伸。床板上，長出了一層薄薄的、粉紅色的肉膜。它就是肉。那肉膜的紋理，那些細微的、如同葉脈般的脈絡，與我每日刮削的那塊牆體，如出一轍。

我沒有驚訝，也沒有恐懼。我只是伸出手，用指甲輕輕刮了一下。一層凝固的、溫熱的油脂。我整塊把它放進嘴裡。

我的唾液開始滲透它。最先釋放出來的，是一股壓倒性的、幾乎要將人溺斃的甜味，不是蔗糖的甜，而是熟透了的無花果，那種已經在溶解邊緣的、帶着蜜香的甜。

當我用臼齒輕輕將它碾開時，那層薄脆的外殼無聲地塌陷了。內裡並非空心，而是一種奇異的、富有嚼勁的口感，像是在咀嚼一塊充滿膠質的、燉得極其軟爛的肉筋，但纖維之間，又夾雜着一些極其細微的、沙礫般的顆粒感，它們在我的齒間發出幾乎聽不見的、細碎的摩擦聲。

然後，第二層味道才遲遲地浮現。那是在甜味的最底層，一種極其微弱的、杜松子酒的植物香氣，但它已經失去了酒精的辛辣，變得像泡在福馬林裡的植物標本，只剩下一個空洞的、被記憶扭曲了的氣味輪廓。

嚐到了熟悉的、混雜着父親氣息的甜腥味。

杜松子

我花了三天的時間，吃光了。

我不再需要鏡子了。

我坐在床沿，看着自己的手。手背的皮膚，在牆體散發的微光下，顯得有些薄，有些透，像一層濕潤的蟬翼。我能看到皮膚底下，那些淡青色的血管，像一張細密的、不斷蔓延的根系圖。我盯着那圖案，看了很久很久。

我的目光，沿着其中一條最粗的、淡青色的主脈絡緩緩移動。在它即將分岔的前一刻，我的視線已經自動轉向了左邊那條更細的支流。在那個支流的末端，一個微小的、幾乎看不見的節點，如預期般地出現。

這不是記憶，也不是辨認。這更像是在閱讀一張早已刻在自己視網膜最深處的地圖。每日，刮刀的刀刃傳回我指尖的、那種刮過牆體紋理的觸感，與此刻我皮膚底下血液搏動的節奏。

我低下頭，用舌尖，舔了一下自己的手背。

一陣奇異的平靜，潮水般將我淹沒。

我躺下來，躺在父親睡過的那張、已經被刮得乾乾淨淨的床板上。閉上眼睛。感覺到一顆新的牙齒，正從我的上顎，安靜而又堅定地，確實地破肉而出。

可能概括福柯思想的四種詩意表達

19 Dec 25 UTC Category: Philosophy

這不是一隻煙斗。
This is not a pipe.
Magritte

只要知識依然與其鉸鏈嵌合，它就從屬於「對象」或「意向性」的統一。這一直是現象學的特徵：看與説、光與語言，終究在對象身上匯合。對象就是樞紐，讓可見性visibilities和陳述statements嵌合。我們自以為説出了所見的、看見了所説的。光與詞，在現象學的圈套裏，繞着同一個圓心旋轉。

「這不是一隻煙斗」，或是布郎肖所説的「言説不是看」，就是第一個偉大翻轉：可見性與陳述的徹底斷裂The disjunction。

知識不再圍繞對象旋轉，對象本身崩裂了，裂成了光與語言間的裂縫。看與説不再對應，沉積為兩塊異質的地層strata。

看（seeing）是光的建築、全景敞視監獄，是解剖台。
説（speaking）是檔案、分類學、刑法典。

這兩者並不重疊。看煙斗的圖像，和説「這不是煙斗」之間有一片「非關係」的虛空。知識不是融合，而是它們在深淵邊緣相互補足的鬥爭。福柯將知識從主客關係中解放來，安置在光與語言的「非關係」之中。

上帝之死也是人之死。
The death of God is also the death of Man.
Nietzche

經院哲學將「力」從屬於「形式form」：上帝的形式、君主的形式、法律的形式。權力為所有物，君主手握之烈焰劍向下輻射。福柯讓權力掙脱了法律，它不再説「你不能做什麼」，反而問「你能做什麼」。它是純粹的戰略：煽動、誘導、生產。如果無限的神學形式隨着上帝的死去崩塌，那麼以「有限性」為基礎的「人」之形式，這個十九世紀的發明，也無法獨善其身。「人」只是力與力的暫時組合，沙灘上的一張臉。當構成「人」的力場發生變異，「人」的形式也將被抹去。形式是暫時的，唯有力的關係是永恆的風暴。

內部只是外部的褶曲。
The Inside is merely the fold of the Outside.
Michaux & Deleuze

我們曾以另一種方式構想主體。首先有一個源頭，一個笛卡爾式的「我思Cogito」，或者康德的先驗主體。它是封閉的堡壘，擁有自發的內部，向外投射意義。

但在福柯那裏，正如在康德的道德律中一樣：內部並不存在，或者説，內部是衍生的。這就像那艘愚人船，希臘人的自我技術。主體不是原初的實體，而是操作的結果。這個操作就是摺疊。如果知識是地層，權力就是外部的風暴。只有把外部拉進來摺疊成一個內部的口袋，我們才能有一個主體。帆船將風（外部的力）摺疊進帆布，轉化為推進的速度。

主體化就是將權力的力線彎曲，使其作用於自身。希臘人將「統治他人的權力」摺疊為「治理自我的權力」。 因此，主體不是實體，而是一個過程。我們不是「擁有」一個靈魂，我們「摺疊」出一個靈魂。

即將到來的超人。
The Superman to come.
Rimbaud & Nietzsche

在康德的第四個公式中，官能進入了無序的運作，不協調的和諧。 對於福柯而言，這對應著「超褶曲The Superfold」的時代，他在《詞與物》結尾所預言的未來。

在古典時代，力被摺疊為「上帝」；在現代，力被摺疊為「人」。正如康德的崇高將想像力推向了極限，當代技術將「生命」與「語言」推向了極限。 「人」的形式正在消散，因為構成人的三種力，生命、勞動、語言，正在進入新的組合。

Machinic Deleuzoid

02 Oct 25 UTC Category: Philosophy

Organs and the Hierarchical

In the BwO framework, “organs” symbolize the organ-ization that defines the very structure of bodies, systems, and societies. The name “BwO” is itself a sufficient clue to what it is primarily at stake of thought. According to D&G, every organized entity—whether an organism, process, or social system—suffers from being fixed in a particular arrangement. This persistent impulse toward organization is not a flaw but a feature of all living and systemic forms.

  • Functionalism: Organs exist to serve an overall purpose.
  • Stratification: These organs are arranged in a hierarchy that governs the system.

D&G criticize this “molar structure” because it solidifies the body into a closed system, limiting its capacity for fluidity. The rigidity is not inherent in the organs themselves but arises from their fixed symbolic assignments and territorial boundaries.

Bodies as Flow, and Assemblage

Everything in our world, traffic, money, tears, rivers, is composed of flows. In our own bodies, flows of blood, hormones, and waste are constantly moving from one pole (source) to another (destination). These flows, when they connect, form what D&G call partial objects or desiring machines. For example, think of the simple connection made when your mouth touches the tip of a straw to sip a drink. Such partial objects are not whole things like cars or buildings; they are dynamic links that, together, form the basis of D&G’s political–philosophical ontology.

Assemblage, in french agencement, usually translated as “putting together”, “arrangement”, “layout”, or “fitting”. Agencement is not a static term, not the arrangement or organization but the process of arranging and organizing, to assemble. Assemblage is a collection of heterogeneous elements, diverse things brought together in particular relations. The elements also include the qualities present and the affects (情動). Not just what it “is”, also what it “can” do. An example is D&G’s re-reading of a Freud’s case: A child was touched by the sight of a horse pulling a carriage through his window. The horse collapsed in the street and was being whipped by the driver. It was about to die. This scene is an assemblage, horse–omnibus–street, as a collection of objects in a particular relations, it is also:

a list of active and passive affects in the context of the individuated assemblage it is part of: having eyes blocked by blinders, having a bit and a bridle, being proud, having a big peepee-maker, pulling heavy loads, being whipped, falling, making a din with its legs, biting, etc. These affects circulate and are transformed within the assemblage: what a horse “can do”.

Assemblages create territories, more than just spaces: they make stakes, claims and expressions. What do I perceive from you? Chikawaa toys, screaming, violent Angus, cooking meat, chocalate clothes. The traits in this partial description constitute an assemblage, yet they just partially make you up, expressing a certain quality of identity (同一性). The point is that this assemblage does not have to consist of these particular elements. Anthropologists Heather Horst and Daniel Miller once studies about mobile phones in Jamaica:

There is no fixed thing called a cell phone or fixed group called Jamaicans. Rather, this book will seek to find out what Jamaicans have become in the light of their use of cell phone and what cell phone has become in the light of its use by Jamaicans.

Assemblages of a mobile phone should also include people elsewhere, becoming private publicly, having an iPhone Pro Max Ultra Super, and what the assemblage does: how it shapes space, transforms behaviour, rings, texting. Here, we encounter the posthumanist shift, that mechanical implants would radically alter our assemblage–cyborg body. Becoming posthuman is more than just installing prosthesis on a pre-becoming biological organic body and expect nothing happens except for the one-dimensional extension or scalar amplification of extant functional organs — a zombie (organs without body). Assemblages are not just things that accumulate together to articulate into formation. Rather than putting an apple in your refrigerator, it is more like a cockroach leg in a pot of lohikeitto (or 皇帝用金鋤頭). We cannot think technology in isolation, taken out of every context respectively. Not an individuated human with an isolated phone, but a body–phone–doomscrolling–etc.

What is Desire?

Traditional Western philosophy has typically defined desire in terms of what is missing or lacking:

  • Plato: Desire is the impulse to fill a sense of void (e.g., hunger as a lack of food).
  • Kant: The faculty which by means of its representations is the cause of the actuality of the objects of those representations
  • Freud: Desire is driven by repressed instincts (like Oedipus complex).
  • Lacan: Desire is the endless chase after the elusive objet-petit-a, the signifier of lack

These views share common themes: they all locate desire in the sense of absence, tie it to a subject-centered interiority, and see it as something that must be controlled or sublimated in opposition to social norms.

D&G simply put desire as the production of reality: “desire produces, [and] its product is real”. Unlike Kant’s who distinguishes between pathological–irrational and moral–rational desires, D&G sees desire as both creative and productive before any social structures. Marx describes nature as humanity’s “inorganic body”, yet social representation functions precisely to separate desire from reality. Much like Spinoza’s idea of superstition limiting a body’s potential. This introduces a retroactive injection of so-called “needs” and scarcity into a desire–reality relations that are immediate onto the unconscious, species-being level. Consequently, individuals and groups internalize a sense of deficiency, believing they need something that was, in fact, originally produced by desire but later claimed by the social order.

D&G argue that desire is not merely a reaction to lack but is both a producer and a product—a process they call desire-production. Rather than being confined to the mind or a fixed state of lack, desire is an active, creative force that connects flows and assembles partial objects into ever-changing configurations. For example, A baby feeding at the breast is not driven by “hunger as lack” but is engaging in a desiring-machine process. Mouth-breast assemblage produces flows of pleasure, crying, touching, etc. Similarly, a musician improvising with an instrument allows rhythmic and harmonic disruptions to break away from fixed structures, creating new flows of expression. The journey of learning an instrument requires a significant amount of bare repetition— scales, arpeggios, runnings, etc. Once one reaches a certain level of proficiency, improvisation becomes possible. Free jazz musicians start from a familiar “basin of attractors” (notes and chord, tonic, dominant, M7, whatsoever), to the unexpected change of keys, tonal language, while maintaining its consistency as a piece of music. This is an example of de-territorialization. This term is intended to replace schizophrenia. Territorialization is accompanied by processes of coding, de-coding and re-coding: Marriage might de-code an eligible status of bachelor of a young man, and re-code him as a husband not-available. In The Communist Manifesto, Marx and Engels described this process as “strips of its halo”—everything with intrinsic value and replaces it with strict quantitative, monetary value. This process of commodification enables exploitation, but also frees desire from being captured by social encodings, releasing huge amounts of free-flowing energy that capital cannot always re-capture for private accumulation. D&G calls this “schizophrenia”, not in the sense of mental illness, but the free, decoded flow of desire. It is the limit of capitalism. However, desire never appears in absolutely pure form, it is always expressed through codes and institutions (Like Lacan’s “Desire is the desire of the Other's desire”).

D&G also critique the psychoanalytic Oedipal model for reducing desire to a “family drama,” arguing that this model—along with capitalist family structures—ignores desire’s decentralized and impersonal character. They expand the discussion by comparing desire to:

  • Will to Power (Nietzsche): An affirmative, life-affirming force
  • Élan vital (Bergson): A manifestation of creative evolution.
  • Conatus (Spinoza): The fundamental drive for every being to persist in its existence.

However, while this posthuman perspective decouples desire from strictly human agency, it raises questions about how agency remains possible when desire is seen as entirely decentralized from human, and it may risk romanticizing escape underestimating structural constraints.

Desire-Production

While flows are central to D&G’s thought, the universe is also marked by breaks—points where continuous flows are interrupted and reconfigured. Think of the process of fuel moving through a car engine: it flows from the gas tank to the engine, yet along the way, there are mechanical breaks that convert energy, set pistons in motion, and ultimately get the wheels turning. In our bodies, everyday actions like playing a clarinet, using a touchscreen, or even receiving a paper cut serve as breaks where flows diverge or recombine.

Desiring machines operate through these interruptions. When a car breaks down, it is not the entire machine that fails but the network of partial objects and connections that has been disrupted. D&G describe this as an inherent quality of desire-production: it constantly undergoes exchanges and expenditures through a multitude of connections, which in turn drive its own dissolution—a process they consider “the law of conservation.” While organization restricts the body, desiring machines inherently resist fixation and continuously push toward disintegration.

Before addressing the BwO directly, D&G introduced the concept of the abstract machine in Guattari’s Machinic Unconscious. This abstraction is not the conceptual abstraction of epistemologists, nor Hegelian dialectics, but the deterritorialization. Rather than being tied to a universal time or fixed semiotic properties, the abstract machine is a fluid assemblage of symbol-machines operating across various levels of reality. It establishes and dismantles hierarchies continuously.

Whenever we discuss the abstract machine, we always point to a consistent and horizontal emergence under specific historical conditions. This is the anti-structuralist methodology, never presupposes a transcendent, invariant system (like Lacan’s signifier, Althusser’s ideology or Strauss’ language) or a central series. Some may argue that capitalism always enforces a command centered on the “capital” and organ-izes a complete structure. Yet capitalism too is governed by the abstract machine of power-economic organisation and uses gigantic “molecular” machines to deterritorialize flows. It also arranges “black-holes” along paths. Black-holes are “traps” that reproduce constraining forms of subjectivity, suck-in and aggregate semiotic contents only to re-situate them in a repressive, serialized, hyper-charged form, as to condition desire.

Returning to the body, D&G draw on Spinoza’s Ethics, where Spinoza remarks, “We feel that a body [or thing] is affected in manifold ways.” For Spinoza, the mind’s power emerges from bodily sensations and their interplay with the limits of order (affects). The BwO is seen as an “embryo” of intensities—a state of virtual potential that has not yet crystallized into an organized system of organs.

Body-without-Organs

The BwO should be understood as a real, transformative entity rather than a mere metaphor. By its very nature, it resists a complete, stable description—precisely because it stands in opposition to organized, fixed organisms. D&G propose that beneath every organized body lies a primordial, undifferentiated metaphysical substrate—a body not yet interpellated or disciplined into a fixed subjectivity. In this state, partial objects (breasts, lips, even the anus) press against one another within a field of pure, immanent drives. Organisms experience this primordial body much like a mass of soft, shifting 豆腐花 crawling beneath the skin. It serves as a counterflow to the production of fixed connections—a substrate of primordial fluidity that cannot be penetrated but remains essential to the constitution of desire.

For D&G, Lacan’s objet-petit-a does not stand for “lack”. Precisely that we have lost objet-petit-a, desire can be realized and emancipated into becoming-flow. Repression is necessarily structured; in other words, there is no such thing as primal repression. Or more fundamentally, repression does not exist at all. In psychoanalysis, the attempt to bring unconscious content into consciousness is seen by D&G as a destruction and annihilation of the unconscious, as it “suffocates the production of desire.” They seek to restore the purity of desire—it is not related to lack, nor is there anything that needs to be repressed. However, it (the product) can only exist through the process of assemblage.

The BwO defines a limit of desire’s insistence towards disorganisation. Unlike the production of connections that occurs with desiring machines, BwO is of itself entirely non-production. It simultaneously repulses, attracts the production of connections (the desiring-machines), this antagonism in their attempts to penetrate the BwO produces “paranoiac-machine”. It anti-produces connections. This stands in opposition to the methodologies of psychoanalysis and structuralism, which define desire as “lack” and castrate it, expanding its boundaries until it becomes the primary social value (Althusser’s ideological apparatus is a typical example. It outlines the concrete production of society as a machine, then retreating to re-presentational ideology, thus failing to overcome subjectivity, and only restoring the paranoid psychotic machine).

Capitalism, with its abstract machine, manipulates flows at the level of production by controlling economic-power organizations—not through ideology per se, but the resonant redundancy of the organism where desire is continuously linked, produced, and captured. In this sense, the BwO functions like a “cartography,” constantly redrawn by the movement of abstract machines that sketch lines of flight, black holes, and stratifications of desire.

The body without organs is not a body, but a plane of immanence. [...] For the BwO is all of that: necessarily a Place, necessarily a Plane, necessarily a Collectivity (assembling elements, things, plants, animals, tools, people, powers, and fragments of all of these; for it is not "my" body without organs, instead the "me" (moi) is on it, or what remains of me, unalterable and changing in form, crossing thresholds).

Or in other words, the BwO is the virtual ground of an actual assemblage. It is a reservoir of potentiality. One can’t desire without a BwO; Desire means “wanting to be part of an assemblage”. A completely deterritorialization is inhabitable for organisms, we all need some organization. The reason for D&G to posit the BwO is that they believe if we take the world at face value, one cannot explain how stuff organizes and unorganizes. Transcendental forces are conditions of organization. The BwO allows us to think bodies (animals, the State, language, semiotics, etc.) as radical contingency and potential differences.

D&G warn that the BwO may lead to extreme outcomes:

  • Rigified BwO (Cancerous): Excessive anti-production results in blocked flows (e.g., addiction).
  • Empty BwO (Paranoiac): Unchecked escape of flows can trigger schizophrenic breakdowns (e.g., psychedelic-induced delirium).
  • Generated BwO (Healthy): A dynamic balance between production and anti-production transforms the body into an open field for experimentation.

This is how it should be done: Lodge yourself on a stratum, experiment with the opportunities it offers, find an advantageous place on it, find potential movements of deterritorialization, possible lines of flight, experience them, produce flow conjunctions here and there, try out continuums of intensities segment by segment, have a small plot of new land at all times.

Within this framework:

BwO as “the field of intensities”

Flows converge into non-organic intensities—non-expressional forces such as emotion, energy, and sensory resonance that resist capture by fixed semiotics. These intensities emerge when conventional organic functions are suspended, as during extreme experiences (pain, ecstasy, trance, musical climax). They operate at a molecular level, reflecting microscopic differences that oppose the fixed, molar categorizations (like genres or social identities). This is akin to the phenomenon of “起乩”, where divine entities are believed to possess performers during rituals, temporarily transforming their bodies into mere containers of raw intensities and creating “smooth space”—an unstratified plane that allows desire to flow freely.

BwO as Becoming

Here, “becoming” refers to the constant, unbounded flow of difference production—a process that is about transformation rather than reaching a predetermined destination. Russian revolutionary anarchist, Bakunin writes, being is identified with becoming:

To be real… is to become…: i.e., movement always and eternally resulting from the infinite sum of all the particular movements down to the infinitely small, the totality of the mutual actions and reactions and the ceaseless transformations of all the things that appear and disappear in turn.

What we term a molar entity is, for example, the woman as defined by her form, endowed with organs and functions and assigned as a subject… [Becoming-woman is] not imitating or assuming the female form, but emitting particles that enter the relation of movement and rest, or the zone of proximity, of a microfemininity, in other words, that produce in us a molecular woman, create the molecular woman.

Becoming-woman does not have to do with being a woman, being like a woman or standing in for a woman. Becomings are always molecular deterritorializations, effects destabilizing dominant molar forms and relations. Thus, there is no “becoming-man”, because the molar entity par excellence is “the rational, white, adult, masculine male”. Becomings only resonate to the figure constituted by dualisms around dominant man-image: male/female, adult/child, white/non-white, rational/emotional, masculine/feminine. Both men and women must become-woman.

Sado-Masochism

BwO can be visualized through sadomasochism. Pain is something to be avoided, something that causes the opposition of pleasure. The sadomasochist has taken their body and actualized one of its potentials, that pain can now be pleasurable, like when Foucault says that the normative/vanilla view of sexuality is not normal in an abstract sense but is merely one of the potentials that has been actualized by society. SM reinvents pleasure, that the antithesis of pleasure (pain) becomes part of its foundation. As Foucault writes,

Sexuality must not be thought of as a kind of natural given which power tries to hold in check, or as an obscure domain which knowledge tries gradually to uncover. It is the name that can be given to a historical construct.

D&G extend their analysis to sado-masochism by distinguishing between two modes:

Organised SM (Rigid BwO)

In this form, SM is reduced to a master-slave dynamic reminiscent of Freud’s “father-superego.” It reinforces a binary system of pain and pleasure that ultimately serves the rigid symbolic order—a pathology of the organized body.

“Healthy” BwO

It escapes (not only by rejection) symbolic structures by dissolving fixity. Such as rejecting the transcendental signifier of phallus in psychoanalysis, or as a symbol of masculinity. The sadist does not seek control over others but aligns with abstract forces; The masochist does not submit but transforms pain into sensory intensity. SM approaches the BwO state of depersonalisation, but with risk being reabsorbed into the symbolic order.

How do you make youself a BwO?

This is the title of the fifth plateau of A Thousand Plateus, and the ethic is addressed directly there: Make yourself a BwO, and here’s how to do it.

Where psychoanalysis says, "Stop, find your self again," we should say instead, "Let's go further still, we haven't found our BwO yet, we haven't sufficiently dismantled our self." Substitute forgetting for anamnesis, experimentation for interpretation. Find your body without organs. Find out how to make it. It's a question of life and death, youth and old age, sadness and joy. It is where everything is played out.

Everybody has a BwO, or some BwO. A BwO is not a space or a space, it is an occasion for experimenting with intensities, a continuous self-constructing/associating milieu. Meanwhile, desiring-production is by nature indeterminate, as it is subjected to the determination of social institutions and representations. The BwO stages the struggle of desire to escape determination, whether it is instinctual, habitual or social, designated for the human potential for freedom.

The question is fundamentally that of the body—the body they steal from us in order to fabricate opposable organisms. This body is stolen first from the girl: Stop behaving like that, you’re not a little girl anymore, you’re not a tomboy, etc. The girl’s becoming is stolen first, in order to impose a history, or prehistory, upon her. The boy’s turn comes next, but it is by using the girl as an example, by pointing to the girl as the object of his desire, that an opposed organism, a dominant history is fabricated for him too. The girl is the first victim, but she must also serve as an example and a trap. That is why, conversely, the reconstruction of the body as a Body without Organs, the anorganism of the body, is inseparable from a becoming-woman.

Girl, or a Shōjo, would always be a becoming-woman and never become a woman. “One may argue that shōjo constitute their own gender, neither male or female but rather something importantly detached from the productive economy of hetero-sexual reproduction.” The Shōjo is a becoming-molecular, a line of flight. “shōjo means ‘not-quite-female female’” Shōjo, the girl, is an “in-between” (au milieu). "Girls do not belong to an age group, sex, order, or kingdom: they slip in everywhere, between orders, acts, ages, sexes; they produce η molecular sexes on the line of flight in relation to the dualism machines they cross right through” The girl is an experiment, the BwO.

Postscript

The reason why many couldn’t understand French philosophy properly, is that they never read literature. Say for Proust, Kafka, Joyce, Marllame, … French philosophers especially love to elaborate their notion through analysing specific writers. For example, Foucault on Sade; Lacan on Joyce and Kafka; Deleuze on Kafka and Proust.

Actually, I’m not a fan of the notion “post-structuralist” or “post-poststructuralist” because it contains an inherent paradox: If you truly believe [someone] is a post-structuralist, then they cease to be one.

If post-structuralism is understood as a turn toward genealogy, a Hegelian dialectical reversal, or the inscription of unconscious drives, then it is something produced precisely as structuralist internal negation. In this logic, deconstruction is merely a prelude to the dialectical tension between structuralism and post-structuralism (as the antithesis within structuralism). If we accept this formulation, then the very name of “post-structuralism” gains its legitimacy only as a presence emerging from this dialectic.

The real problem arises when we attempt to confine [someone] within a particular theoretical–historical genealogy. Even if this categorization is necessary and inevitable, we must acknowledge that sublimation is at play here. What sublimation? Just like Narcissus withers upon recognizing himself in the mirror, post-structuralism, in the process of evolving itself, encounters structuralism and collapses. What we do is akin to a choir, capturing the traces of this dialectic.

Thus, the significance of psychoanalysis (or any other “post-structuralism”) lies in its ability to demonstrate, through the powerless sighs and desperate wails of failure, how the impossibility inherent in subjectivity becomes visible. If this is the case, then true post-structuralism does not exist. If it did, it would only have two possible tasks:

  1. to retroactively mark to position of impossibility after a decisive historical rupture;
  2. to show how ideology facilitates our “leap of faith” embracing into meaning.

Both the tasks, however, ultimately point in the same direction: proving the attempt to exhaust impossibility — only oscillates endlessly between success and failure, just as psychoanalysis demonstrates the history of human desire.

Today, every argument of the structural/post-structuralism divide inevitably produces Derrida-styled discourse, where the chase of traces becomes traces itself. This applies to even contemporary theorists like D&G, who explicitly reject dialectics and psychoanalysis (?). What we continue to repeat is the same process: a compulsive return to an unfinished drive before the future arrives.

This work is, of course, valuable. But we must not confuse one crucial point: the structural/post-structural distinction can only be properly articulated either at the moment when this dialectic is fully resolved, or it can only be that all the post-structuralisms are still not post enough. In this sense, true post-structuralism should serve as the gravestone of our era, if we does not end up in a zombie apocalypse, fallout scenario or ...
